title: Download OO container images
content:
To install an application, you need to download the required installation images. You need to:

  • Generate an image download tool package.
  • Run the download script inside the tool package to download the required installation images.

Generate the download bundle

The generate_download_bundle.sh compares the images listed in the image-set.json file with those that already exist in the specified image organization of the specified registry. It will only download the missing images.

  1. Log on to the first control plane node.
  2. Run the following command to change the directory.  
    cd  ${CDF_HOME}/tools/generate-download
  3. Run the command together with the options required by your deployment. For example, run the following command: 
    ./generate_download_bundle.sh --chart <OO helm chart file> -o <org name> [-d <destination dir>]

    Where:
    • <OO helm chart file>: The absolute path to the OO Helm chart .tgz archive. For example: oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+26.x.x.tgz.
    • <org name>: The organization in the image registry that contains the installation images. By default, it's hpeswitom.
    • <destination dir>: The directory where the output .zip file is created. The default location is the current directory.

    The generate_download_bundle.sh compares the images needed by the suite with the images that already exist in the cluster and generates a .zip file, offline-download.zip that enables you to download the required images from Docker Hub.
    For example:

    ./generate_download_bundle.sh --chart oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+26.x.x.tgz -o hpeswitom

    The script saves the offline-download.zip file under the current working directory. To save the file in a different directory, use the "-d" option to specify a new directory. You will receive the following messages indicating that you have successfully generated the offline-download.zip file:

    [INFO] 2020-07-31 17:58:46 : ** Generating the offline image download bundle ...
[INFO] 2020-07-31 17:58:50 : Completed generation of offline-download.zip in /tmp

    Download the required installation images

    1. Log on to the first control plane node. If the first control plane node can't access Docker Hub, transfer the offline-download.zip file to a Linux server that can access Docker Hub.
    2. Extract the .zip package to a directory. If you can't access Docker Hub directly, set up the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. For example, run the following commands to set the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. Replace the placeholders with your actual server and port. 
      export http_proxy="<http://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
      export https_proxy="<https://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
    3. Go to the directory where you extracted the offline-download.zip package.
    4. Run the following command: 
      ./downloadimages.sh [-r <image repository URL>] [-u <username>]  [-d <image download directory>] [-c on|off] [-o <org name>]

      Where:

      • <image repository URL>: Specify the -r option if you want to download the images from a repository other than Docker Hub.
      • Replace <username> with the Docker Hub username.
      • If you don't specify the credentials here, you will be prompted to specify them when you run the command.
      • <image download directory>: The directory where the container images will download. The default value is /var/opt/cdf/offline.
      • The -c option is used to verify the digital signature of the images during the download. The default setting is off, which doesn't verify the signature.
      • <org name>: The organization in the image registry that contains the installation images. By default, this is hpeswitom. This option is mandatory if you aren't using the default organization name.

    To see the full list of options for the downloadimages.sh command, run the following command:
    ./downloadimages.sh –h
    The command also has a -p option to provide your password. The -p option doesn't support single quotes (in other words, don't include single quotes in the password).

     
    By selecting the -p option, you are disabling or bypassing security features, thereby exposing the system to increased security risks. By using this option, you understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same.
     
    OpenText encourages you to use some other password options, which aren't provided by OpenText. By implementing the -p option, you may expose the system to increased security risks.     Transfer the images to the control plane node

    If you downloaded the images to a server other than the first control plane node, transfer the images to a directory on the first control plane node. By default, the images should be placed under the /var/opt/cdf/offline directory.

    The images will be uploaded by the uploadimages.sh script later. The image upload requires up to 2 times the image size space in the target image directory. For example, if you choose to use the default /var/opt/cdf/offline directory, ensure that you have 2 times the OMT and suite image size space under the /var/opt/cdf/offline directory of the control plane node.
